#Text=THE DEVIL IN MANUSCRIPT

#Text=On a bitter evening of December , I arrived by mail in a large town , which was then the residence of an intimate friend , one of those gifted youths who cultivate poetry and the belles-lettres , and call themselves students at law .
#Text=My first business , after supper , was to visit him at the office of his distinguished instructor .

#Text=As I have said , it was a bitter night , clear starlight , but cold as Nova Zembla , -- the shop-windows along the street being frosted , so as almost to hide the lights , while the wheels of coaches thundered equally loud over frozen earth and pavements of stone .
#Text=There was no snow , either on the ground or the roofs of the houses .

#Text=The wind blew so violently , that I had but to spread my cloak like a main-sail , and scud along the street at the rate of ten knots , greatly envied by other navigators , who were beating slowly up , with the gale right in their teeth .
#Text=One of these I capsized , but was gone on the wings of the wind before he could even vociferate an oath .
#Text=After this picture of an inclement night , behold us seated by a great blazing fire , which looked so comfortable and delicious that I felt inclined to lie down and roll among the hot coals .
#Text=The usual furniture of a lawyer 's office was around us , -- rows of volumes in sheepskin , and a multitude of writs , summonses , and other legal papers , scattered over the desks and tables .

#Text=But there were certain objects which seemed to intimate that we had little dread of the intrusion of clients , or of the learned counsellor himself , who , indeed , was attending court in a distant town .
#Text=A tall , decanter-shaped bottle stood on the table , between two tumblers , and beside a pile of blotted manuscripts , altogether dissimilar to any law documents recognized in our courts .
#Text=My friend , whom I shall call Oberon , -- it was a name of fancy and friendship between him and me , --
#Text=my friend Oberon looked at these papers with a peculiar expression of disquietude .
#Text=" I do believe , " said he , soberly , " or , at least , I could believe , if I chose , that there is a devil in this pile of blotted papers .

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text= And of mine , too , " thought I.

column1: #Text=" You remember , " continued Oberon , " how the hellish thing used to suck away the happiness of those who , by a simple concession that seemed almost innocent , subjected themselves to his power .

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text= Nothing , " replied I , " unless the spell be hid in a desire to turn novelist , after reading your delightful tales . "

column1: #Text=" Novelist ! " exclaimed Oberon , half seriously .
#Text=" Then , indeed , my devil has his claw on you !

#Text=But we will be the last and only victims ; for this night I mean to burn the manuscripts , and commit the fiend to his retribution in the flames .

_	_	_	_

#Text= Burn your tales ! " repeated I , startled at the desperation of the idea .

column1: #Text=" Even so , " said the author , despondingly .
#Text=" You cannot conceive what an effect the composition of these tales has had on me .

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text= That does make a difference , indeed , " said I.

column1: #Text=" They have been offered , by letter , " continued Oberon , reddening with vexation , " to some seventeen booksellers .

#Text=One man publishes nothing but school-books ; another has five novels already under examination .

_	_	_	_

#Text= What a voluminous mass the unpublished literature of America must be ! " cried I.

column1: #Text=" Oh , the Alexandrian manuscripts were nothing to it ! " said my friend .
#Text=" Well , another gentleman is just giving up business , on purpose , I verily believe , to escape publishing my book .
#Text=" A fact ! " said Oberon .

#Text=" In short , of all the seventeen booksellers , only one has vouchsafed even to read my tales ; and he -- a literary dabbler himself , I should judge -- has the impertinence to criticise them , proposing what he calls vast improvements , and concluding , after a general sentence of condemnation , with the definitive assurance that he will not be concerned on any terms . "
